title-group.article-title: Case Study: You Decide: The Company You Keep

abstract.p: Unfortunately, the unethical behavior of employees, managers and executives has resulted in billions of dollars of stolen wealth, causing financial and personal destruction for thousands of victims. Surprisingly, roughly 70% of white-collar crimes involve persons educated beyond high school; and individuals with the highest levels of education cause the highest losses of corporate wealth. Upon entering the workforce, finance students must prove themselves in terms of the quality of their work and the quality of their character, sidestepping those who prey on their naïveté and resisting the temptation to participate in illegal gain. Dennis Levine's insider-trading case illustrates the most typical motivations of white-collar criminals; however, the motivations of his friends and co-conspirators are more complex and perhaps more tragic. Students are immersed in a fascinating study of ethical and legal boundaries, one that considers how the social situation influences human behavior.
